WHAT.TITLE: ¿Qué?
WHAT.BODY:
Esta herramienta ofrece una introducción al aprendizaje automático a través de experiencias prácticas para entrenar sistemas de aprendizaje automático y construir cosas con ellos.

Consiste en un sencillo entorno de aprendizaje guiado para entrenar modelos de aprendizaje automático capaces de identificar texto, números o imágenes.

Esto complementa los esfuerzos existentes para introducir y enseñar a programar a los niños, agregando estos modelos a Scratch (la plataforma educativa de programación usada en todo el mundo), permitiendo a los niños crear proyectos y construir juegos con los modelos de aprendizaje automático que ellos mismos han entrenado.

Para aprender más, ver:

WHY.TITLE: ¿Por qué?
WHY.BODY:
El aprendizaje automático está por todos lados. Usamos sistemas de aprendizaje automático todos los días, por ejemplo, los filtros de detección de correo basura, sistemas de recomendación, servicios de traducciones de idiomas, chatbots y asistentes digitales, motores de búsqueda, y sistemas de detección de fraude.

Pronto será normal que los sistemas de aprendizaje automático manejen nuestros automóviles, y ayuden a los médicos a diagnosticar y tratar nuestras enfermedades.

Es importante que los niños conozcan cómos funciona el mundo. La mejor manera de comprender las capacidades e implicaciones del aprendizaje automático, es usar esta tecnología para poder construir algo ellos mismos.

Para aprender más, leer: 'Introducción a Aprendizaje Automático para niños'

TECH.TITLE: Tecnología
TECH.BODY:
La herramienta está basada enteramente en la web y no requiere ni instalación ni configuración compleja para usarse.

Fue diseñada para su uso en el aula, tanto en escuelas como en clubes de programación para niños dirigidos por voluntarios, y proporciona una página de administración para que los maestros o líderes de grupos puedan administrar y gestionar el acceso de sus estudiantes.

El desarrollo está a cargo de Dale Lane utilizando APIs de IBM Watson Developer Cloud.

FURTHER.TITLE: Further learning
FURTHER.BODY:
Machine Learning for Kids is a useful tool for introducing children to how ML systems are trained, how they are used, and some of the real-world implications of AI applications.

For additional teaching and learning resources, including teaching the internals of ML systems, please see:

LINKS.TITLE: Educational AI resources for children
LINKS.INTRO: This page is a list of further tools and resources for introducing children to artificial intelligence.

ECRAFT2LEARN.BODY1: Ken Kahn has created resources to allow beginners to create AI programs in Snap! (a visual programming environment similar to Scratch).
ECRAFT2LEARN.BODY2: While I've focused on explaining how AI systems are trained and behave (and the real-world implications), eCraft2Learn has fantastic resources that dive deep into how ML systems actually work.
ECRAFT2LEARN.BODY3: The neural net Tic Tac Toe project is particularly fascinating, allowing students to experiment with hyperparameters from Snap.

STEMLEARNING.BODY1: STEM Learning and the UK Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy have created resources for teaching the principles of artificial intelligence.
STEMLEARNING.BODY2: These resources include Machine Learning for Kids projects, supplemented with teaching notes, presentation materials, prompt cards, and practical “unplugged” activities

RASPBERRYPI.BODY1: The Raspberry Pi Foundation provides resources for Code Clubs, with step-by-step instructions for a variety of creative projects.
RASPBERRYPI.BODY2: Their machine learning pathway includes a variety of projects from Machine Learning for Kids.

APPSFORGOOD.BODY1: Apps for Good are a UK-based not-for-profit that creates resources for teaching technology subjects, that they make freely available to schools.
APPSFORGOOD.BODY2: Their Machine Learning course uses Machine Learning for Kids, and supplements it with a range of additional materials like schemes of work, lesson plans, student workbooks, presentations and more. It makes it easy for schools to deliver ML lessons that put the coding exercises in context.

AIFAMILYCHALLENGE.BODY1: The AI Family Challenge is a free, hands-on AI education program for families. They use Machine Learning for Kids, and supplement it with a lot of additional support, such as technical coaches and mentors, a structured lesson plan and supporting videos.
AIFAMILYCHALLENGE.BODY2: The program is based around a competition that challenges children to think of their own AI project ideas, with the support of their families and technical mentors.

MAGENTADEMOS.BODY1: Online toys that demonstrate different aspects of machine learning, using TensorFlow.js

AIINSCHOOLS.BODY1: The AIinSchools programme provides a free lesson plan for teachers to explain AI to Year 9 (aged 13-14).
AIINSCHOOLS.BODY2: It includes both unplugged classroom activities, and programming activities for training neural networks on GPUs running on AWS.

TEENSINAI.BODY1: Teens in AI use a combination of hackathons, accelerators and bootcamps to support young people aged 12-18 to explore AI.

AI4ALL.BODY1: AI4ALL run summer camps for high school students in the US that give a detailed technical introduction to AI.

CALYPSO.BODY1: Students with programmable Cozmo robots can use the Calypso programming framework to get a hands-on way to experience AI by experimenting with techniques like computer vision and speech recognition.

AIINABOX.BODY1: AI-in-a-Box is a bundle of robots, accessories and teaching resources. The kit can be used to teach projects that cover topics like visual recognition, facial recognition, speech generation and speech recognition.

GOOGLEEXPERIMENTS.BODY1: Simple online experiments to start exploring machine learning, through pictures, drawings, language, and music.

DATASETS.TITLE: Copy a machine learning project template

INTRO.INTRO_1: You can create new machine learning project based on one of these templates.
INTRO.INTRO_2: Each one includes a set of training data that has been collected for you to help you get started quickly.
INTRO.INTRO_3: You will be able to make changes to the training data if you like, or you can go straight to training a machine learning model with it.

MORE.TITLE: Other data sets
MORE.SUMMARY: What other data sets would you like to see?
MORE.DESCRIPTION: Have you got an idea for a data set you'd like to see available here? Or do you have a data set that you'd like to contribute? Please get in touch!

TITANIC.TITLE: Titanic survivors
TITANIC.DESCRIPTION: On 15th April 1912, the RMS Titanic hit an iceberg and sank, killing over 1500 of the passengers and crew. This project includes personal data about hundreds of the passengers. You can use this to train a machine learning model that, if you give it a description of a passenger, can learn to predict the likelihood that they would have survived.
TITANIC.DETAILS:
The 'ticket class' field is a number indicating the type of ticket for the passenger: first class (1), second class (2), or third class (3). 
The 'gender' field is whether the passenger was 'male' or 'female'. 
The 'age' field is the age of the passenger. 
The 'sibl. sp.' is the number of brothers or sisters (siblings) the passenger had on board if they were a child, or the number of husbands or wives (spouses) the passenger had on board if they were an adult. 
The 'par. ch.' field is the number of parents the passenger had on board if they were a child, or the number of children the passenger had on board if they were an adult. 
The 'ticket fare' field is how much they paid for their ticket. 
The 'embarked' field is where they got on board the Titanic, either Cherbourg, Queenstown or Southampton.

CATSANDDOGS.TITLE: Cats and Dogs
CATSANDDOGS.SUMMARY: Recognize photos of cats vs dogs
CATSANDDOGS.DESCRIPTION: Training a machine learning model to recognise photos of cats and dogs is a good simple introduction to image recognition.
CATSANDDOGS.DETAILS: This training dataset of photos from Wikimedia Commons is a good starting set for building your own training data of animal photos

UKNEWSPAPERS.TITLE: UK Newspaper Headlines
UKNEWSPAPERS.SUMMARY: Recognize the use of language in newspaper headlines
UKNEWSPAPERS.DESCRIPTION: Different newspapers use language in different ways. This project includes the main front page headline from four UK newspapers. You can use this to train a machine learning model that can learn to predict the most likely newspaper that a new headline is probably from.
UKNEWSPAPERS.DETAILS: This training dataset includes headlines from the Daily Mail, the Daily Telegraph, the Independent, and The Guardian

PHISHING.TITLE: Phishing
PHISHING.SUMMARY: Predict if a link is a phishing link
PHISHING.DESCRIPTION: Phishing is when a website tries to trick you into giving up sensitive information, by sending you a link to a fake website disguised like a trustworthy one. You can use this to train a machine learning model that can predict if a web address is a real link, or a phishing link to a fake website.
PHISHING.DETAILS:
This training dataset includes attributes of five hundred legitimate web addresses, and five hundred phishing links.

The 'address type' field is 'IP addr' if the link has a numeric IP address like '104.20.74.246' or 'DNS name' if the link has a name-based address like 'machinelearningforkids.co.uk'. 
The 'url length' field groups the training addresses by how long they are. 
The 'shortening' field is 'yes' if the web address uses a shortening service like TinyURL or bit.ly, or 'no' if it doesn't. 
The 'includes @' field is 'yes' if the web address includes an @ symbol, or 'no' if it doesn't. 
The 'port number' field is 'standard' if the web address uses a standard port number like 80 or 443, or 'non-std' if it uses something different. 
The 'domain age' field groups addresses by how long ago the web address in the address was registered. 
The 'redirects' field groups the training addresses by the number of times a web browser is sent to a different address before reaching a final page. 
The 'domain reg' field is 'expiring' if the registration for the web address domain name expires within a year.

NOUGHTSANDCROSSES.SUMMARY: Learn how to play a game
NOUGHTSANDCROSSES.DESCRIPTION: Train a machine learning model to play noughts and crosses, by collecting examples of moves that the computer can use to learn how to predict the best move to make next.
NOUGHTSANDCROSSES.DETAILS: This is an empty template to help you collect your own training data. For instructions on how to use it, download 'Noughts and Crosses' from Worksheets

TOPTRUMPS.TITLE: Kings & Queens Top Trumps
TOPTRUMPS.SUMMARY: Learn how to play a game
TOPTRUMPS.DESCRIPTION: Train a machine learning model to play a Top Trumps game based on English Kings and Queens, by collecting examples of moves that the computer can use to learn how to predict which value to choose.
TOPTRUMPS.DETAILS: This is an empty template to help you collect your own training data. For instructions on how to use it, download 'Top Trumps' from Worksheets.

SONGLYRICS.TITLE: Song lyrics
SONGLYRICS.DESCRIPTION: Train a machine learning model to recognize the type of song based on it's lyrics
SONGLYRICS.DETAILS: This training dataset includes 140 lines from song lyrics - half from children's songs and half from Top 40 songs. It is a good starting set for training a machine learning model to recognize different uses of language.

QUIZ.TITLE: Quiz time!
QUIZ.INTROQUESTION: While you are waiting for the model to finish training, try answering this question.
QUIZ.PREVIOUSLY_ATTEMPTED: You've seen this one before - let's see if you remember what the right answer is this time!
QUIZ.INCORRECT_ANSWER: No, sorry. The correct answer is shown above.

QUESTION_1.QUESTION: In general, what will help machines to learn better?
QUESTION_1.NOTES_1: That isn't the only thing that has an effect. But in general, the more examples it has to learn from, the better it should learn.

QUESTION_2.QUESTION: Which of these would probably be best for training a computer to recognise a photo of an apple?
QUESTION_2.ANSWER_2: Varied photos of different types of apples in different places
QUESTION_2.ANSWER_4: Very, very similar photos of the same apple in the same place
QUESTION_2.NOTES_1: The more varied the examples you can collect, the more the system can learn about how to recognise different pictures of an apple.
QUESTION_2.NOTES_2: If every example you give it is the same apple on the same brown wooden table, it might learn that something is only an apple if it's on a brown wooden table.

QUESTION_3.QUESTION: Which of these would be a good use of machine learning?
QUESTION_3.ANSWER_2: Recognising if an email is spam
QUESTION_3.ANSWER_3: Counting the number of times a button is pressed
QUESTION_3.NOTES_1: Spam filters are a good example of machine learning.
QUESTION_3.NOTES_2: With enough examples of legitimate emails, and enough examples of spam emails, a computer can start to learn how to recognise a spam email.

QUESTION_4.QUESTION: Which of these is NOT a good use of machine learning?
QUESTION_4.ANSWER_1: Sentiment analysis - recognising the mood, tone or emotion in text
QUESTION_4.ANSWER_2: Translating text from one language to another
QUESTION_4.ANSWER_3: Face recognition - recognising a face in a photo and identifying who it is
QUESTION_4.ANSWER_5: Calculating the cost of something in different countries based on exchange rates
QUESTION_4.ANSWER_6: Recommending a movie based on films you've watched before
QUESTION_4.NOTES_1: Tasks that involve following rules which can be worked out are not a good use for machine learning.
QUESTION_4.NOTES_2: A computer isn't going to learn how to apply an exchange rate from examples - we can just tell it what to do.

QUESTION_5.QUESTION: Which of these would be more likely to be successful?
QUESTION_5.ANSWER_1: Collect a small set of examples, train a system, test to see how good it is. Add more examples, train again, and then test again. Repeat until it gets good enough.
QUESTION_5.ANSWER_2: More examples is better, so decide you must need millions of examples. Start collecting a massive set of examples, and spend months collecting more and more and more.
QUESTION_5.NOTES_1: More examples is generally better, but be practical.
QUESTION_5.NOTES_2: Pragmatism is important. Regular testing is useful to let you know how things are going, and help you know when you've done enough.
QUESTION_5.NOTES_3: When you've only got ten examples, another ten examples will probably make a huge difference.
QUESTION_5.NOTES_4: When you've got 100,000 examples, another ten examples probably won't have a noticeable impact.

QUESTION_6.QUESTION: Which of these statements is correct?
QUESTION_6.ANSWER_1: Machine learning is a technique where computers can be trained to perform tasks instead of needing to be given an explicit set of steps to follow
QUESTION_6.ANSWER_3: Machine learning means we don't need to think about problems any more because computers will think for us
QUESTION_6.ANSWER_4: Machine learning has replaced the need for us to learn how to code
QUESTION_6.ANSWER_5: Machine learning can only be done on massive supercomputers

QUESTION_7.QUESTION: A machine learning system trained to recognise pictures with a tree in should be good at which of the following tasks:
QUESTION_7.ANSWER_2: Recognising the emotion in a piece of writing
QUESTION_7.NOTES_1: Machine learning does not mean computers magically learn to do everything.
QUESTION_7.NOTES_2: It means they learn how to do a specific task by being shown examples of that specific task.
QUESTION_7.NOTES_3: If you want it to do something else, you need to train it to do that as well, by giving it examples of that.

QUESTION_8.QUESTION: Alice and Bob both want to train a machine learning system to recognise if text is happy/positive or sad/negative. Which of them will probably train the best system?
QUESTION_8.ANSWER_1: Alice. She has collected 10 varied examples of happy text, and 10 varied examples of sad text
QUESTION_8.ANSWER_2: Bob. He has collected 1000 examples of happy writing and 10 examples of sad writing
QUESTION_8.NOTES_1: Collecting a roughly similar number of examples for each label is a useful technique.
QUESTION_8.NOTES_2: If nearly every example of writing you train a system with is happy, you might end up training the system to assume that sad writing is very unlikely, and that it should assume happy more often.
QUESTION_8.NOTES_4: But, you might want it to do this.
QUESTION_8.NOTES_5: If you're training a system to recognise text where text is happy 98% of the time, training it with that realistic experience might be worth a try.

QUESTION_9.QUESTION: Advanced machine learning technology will always give correct answers. Incorrect answers mean the machine learning technology isn't very good
QUESTION_9.NOTES_3: The technology and algorithms are important. BUT machine learning systems are only as accurate and reliable as the training they are given.
QUESTION_9.NOTES_4: Simple machine learning algorithms with a lot of high quality training can do better than the most advanced machine learning algorithms with a small amount of poor quality training.

QUESTION_10.QUESTION: How can you make sure your collection of animal pictures is good quality for training a machine and doesn't contain human mistakes?
QUESTION_10.ANSWER_1: Manually inspect all of the pictures of animals yourself and make sure you agree with all of the labels
QUESTION_10.ANSWER_2: Ask lots of people to label all the images and keep the training labels that people generally agree on
QUESTION_10.ANSWER_3: Trick question! Humans are always right - machines make mistakes!
QUESTION_10.NOTES_1: Even humans make mistakes and you won't always have time to double check all the training data!
QUESTION_10.NOTES_2: If the task is tricky it can be a good idea to get more than one person to label each image and keep the label that the most humans agree is the right one.

QUESTION_11.QUESTION: A machine trained to identify pictures of "food" or "not food" gives inconsistent results for sandwiches, often putting them in the "not food" class. Which of the following could explain that?
QUESTION_11.ANSWER_1: The human who trained the system doesn't like sandwiches and didn't put any in the training data
QUESTION_11.ANSWER_2: The machine has to be in the right mood for a sandwich so it changes its mind a lot
QUESTION_11.ANSWER_3: Sandwiches are not food. The system is right to be unsure
QUESTION_11.NOTES_1: Machine learning models can only learn from the examples we show them.
QUESTION_11.NOTES_2: It is very easy for humans to accidentally introduce their likes and dislikes into machine learning models so we should be very careful about what training data we use.

QUESTION_12.QUESTION: Which of the following best describes unsupervised learning?
QUESTION_12.ANSWER_1: Writing a program that contains lots of if/else statements to determine the result
QUESTION_12.ANSWER_2: A machine learning algorithm that uses unlabelled data and classifies it based on how similar one dataset is to another
QUESTION_12.ANSWER_3: A machine learning algorithm that uses labelled data and classifies it based on training from example input-output pairs
QUESTION_12.NOTES_1: Unsupervised learning is a type of machine learning, whereas only using if/else statements is not.
QUESTION_12.NOTES_2: Unsupervised learning algorithms are still trained, but the inputs that are given to it are not labelled or classified.
QUESTION_12.NOTES_3: If the data is labelled then this is what's known as supervised learning.

QUESTION_13.QUESTION: Without machine learning, it would be impossible for search engines such as Google to exist.
QUESTION_13.NOTES_1: Whilst many modern search engines do use machine learning, it is possible to create one without it. A basic search engine will just look for documents (web pages) that include the words the user searches for.

DESCRIBEMODEL.TITLE: Understand your machine learning model
DESCRIBEMODEL.TRYITOUT: Try out your machine learning model to see how it uses the decision tree to make predictions

EXPLANATION.EXPL_1: The technique used to create your machine learning model is called a Decision Tree Classifier.
EXPLANATION.EXPL_2: This is not the only way to train a machine learning model. We're using it because it's very quick and easy to train, and it is one of the easiest techniques to understand. This page shows you the decision tree that was created based on the training examples that you have collected.
EXPLANATION.EXPL_3: When you test your model, the computer starts at the top of the tree, and follows a path until it reaches the bottom. The class at the bottom of the tree is the prediction that the machine learning model makes.
EXPLANATION.EXPL_4: At each box in the tree, it reads the test described at the top of the box. If your test values pass the test described in the box, it follows the arrow to the left. If it doesn't pass the test, it follows the arrow to the right.
EXPLANATION.EXPL_5: The samples shown in each box tells you how many examples in your training data matches that part of the decision tree.
EXPLANATION.EXPL_6: The value shown in each box tells you how many examples in your training data passed the test shown at the top (following the left arrow) and how many examples didn't pass the test at the top (following the right arrow).

FAQS.INTRO2: En la siguiente lista puedes encontrar las preguntas y problemas más frecuentes. Si ninguna resuelve tu problema, haz click sobre el resumen para obtener más información.
FAQS.INTRO3: Si sigues atascado o tu problema no está en la lista, por favor, envía un correo a or y reporta el error para que pueda ayudarte.

SCRATCH.TITLE: Problemas con Scratch
SCRATCH.Q1: No se cómo empezar a trabajar con  Scratch
SCRATCH.Q1-A-1: Machine Learning for Kids usa Scratch 2. Scratch necesita Adobe Flash para funcionar, por tanto, necesitas un Sistema operativo y un navegador web que permita trabjar con Flasht (por tanto, y ¡lo sentimos!, no funciona en iPads).
SCRATCH.Q1-A-2: Si no sabes cómo habilitar Flash, puedes descargar un document con instrucciones para hacerlo en.
SCRATCH.Q2: Los menús de Scratch"Cargar proyecto" y  "Guardar proyecto" no funcionan
SCRATCH.Q2-A-1: Si estás usando Safari en  macOS y no funcionan los menús"File -> Cargar Proyecto " y"File -> Guardar proyecto" puede que lo estés ejecutanto en modo seguro..
SCRATCH.Q2-A-2: Aquí tienes las instruccionesFollow the instructions here para comprobar y arreglar este problema.
SCRATCH.Q3: Los bloques de clasificación de aprendizaje automático no funcionen en Scratch
SCRATCH.Q3-A-1: En ocasiones, los bloques de Scratch para un modelo de aprendizaje automático pueden perder la conexión con el servidor. Cuando ocurre ésto, dejarán de ofrecer resultados. .
SCRATCH.Q3-A-2: Puedes comprobar si ésto está ocurriendo con la luz de estatus de la paleta "Más bloques".
SCRATCH.Q3-A-3: Si la luz de estatus está en rojo, significa que algo está mal. Puede tratarse de un problema temporal. Prueba a guardar tu proyecto t (Usando 'Archivo' -> 'Guardar proyecto'),y después refresca la página del navegador. Si la luz de estatus está en verde cuando se vuelva a cagar la página, puedes volver a cargar tu (usando 'Archivo' -> 'Cargar proyecto') para continuar donde lo habías dejado. .
SCRATCH.Q3-A-4: Si la luz de estatus sigue en rojo después de volver a cargar la página, probablemente hay algo mal en el modelo de aprendizaje automático. Ve a la página del Proyecto  "Learn & Test" donde encontrarás los mensajes de error.
SCRATCH.Q3-A-5: Si la luz de estatus está en verde, los bloques deberían de funcionar. Si no obtienes las repuestas esperadas, vuelve a la página "Learn & Test" y comprueba los resultados que devuelve tu modelo. .
SCRATCH.Q5-A-1: Tienes que usar las versions de Scratch que se indican en Machine Learning for Kids. Puedes lanzarla haciendo click sobre los botones  Scratch, o 'Scratch 3', de la página del proyecto.
SCRATCH.Q6: Scratch 3 sólo guarda los proyectos en la carpeta  'Descargas'
SCRATCH.Q6-A-1: Al hacer click en 'Archivo' -> 'Guardar en tu computadora en  Scratch 3, tu Proyecto de Scratch se guardará en local.
SCRATCH.Q6-A-2: Algunos profesores reportaron que se guardaba en la carpeta Descargas en una computadora en la que los alumnos no tenían acceso a dicha carpeta y por tanto no podían acceder a sus proyectos guardados..
SCRATCH.Q6-A-3: Si tienes este problema, busca en tu navegador una opción de configuración del tipo 'Pregunta dónde guardar cada fichero antes de descargarlo'. Si habilitas esta opción los alumnos podrán elegir dónde guarder sus proyetos. .

TRAININGUI.TITLE: Problemas con UI de Entrenamiento
TRAININGUI.Q1: No funciona el arrastrar y soltar imágenes en los contenedores de entrenamiento
TRAININGUI.Q1-A-1: Si usas Internet Explorer no funciona arrastrar imágenes en los contenedores de entrenamiento .
TRAININGUI.Q1-A-2: Lo sentimos. Puedes usar otros navegadores como Firefox o Chrome.. Si no puedes hacerlo, haz click en el botón "www" y pega la URL de las imágenes de entrenamiento. .

MODELS.TITLE: Errores de entrenamiento en modelos de aprendizaje automático
MODELS.Q1-A-1: Los modelos de aprendizaje automático en esta herramienta usan APIs de  IBM Watson.
MODELS.Q1-A-2: Si tienes una cuenta de clase  "no gestionada" , tu profesor tendrá que obtener de IBM Cloud las credenciales para que funcione ApI Watson. En el documento "Primeros pasos"puedes encontrar instrucciones detalladas sobre cómo hacerlo. .
MODELS.Q2: "Se han rechazado las credenciales Watson usadas por la clase"
MODELS.Q2-A-1: Los modelos de aprendizaje automático en esta herramienta usan APIs de IBM Watson
MODELS.Q2-A-2: Si tienes una cuenta de clase "no gestionada" tu profesor habrá obteinido de IBM Cloud las credenciales de Watson API necesarias,   ( como se indica en el documento "Primeros pasos" que está en la parte superior de la página).
MODELS.Q2-A-3: Sin embargo, las credenciales aportadas no funciona. Lo más probable es que hayan sido borradas de IBM Cloud  En este caso, el profesor deb evolver al panel de IBM Cloud para comprobar el estatus de Watson Assistant del servicio de reconocimento de imágenes que han creado.
MODELS.Q3: "Las API keys de Watson Assistant no tienen más espacio de trabajo disponible. "
MODELS.Q3-A-1: Los modelos de aprendizaje automático en esta herramienta usan APIs de IBM Watson.
MODELS.Q3-A-2: Las credenciales de Watson Assistant creada por el profesor tienen limitado el número de modelos de aprendizaje automático que se pueden crear con ellas. Esto se muestra en la interfaz de IBM Cloud donde se crearon"workspaces".
MODELS.Q3-A-3: Si se excede este límite, no se podran entrenar nuevos modelos y se mostrará este mensaje:
MODELS.Q3-A-4: La clase ha superado el límite máximo de modelos que se pueden crear. Por favor, indica a tu profesor que "Las API keys paraWatson ya no tienen más workspaces disponibles".
MODELS.Q3-A-5: Si un alumno que ha entrenado con éxito un modelo lo borra, se libera un workspace que puede ser utilizado por otro alumno. .
MODELS.Q3-A-6: Una forma de evitar este error puede ser limitar el tamaño de las clases. Si hay un número menor de estudiantes que el de workspaces soportados por las credenciales  Watson Assistant eno se superarán los límites.
MODELS.Q3-A-7: Otra forma de evitar este error  consiste en añadir más claves para Watson Assistant API o usar una intancia de Watson Assistant i "plan" que tiene un límite superior.
MODELS.Q4: "Las API Keys para reconocimento de imágenes,  Watson Visual Recognition API no tienen más clasificadores disponibles"
MODELS.Q4-A-1: Los modelos de aprendizaje automático en esta herramienta usan APIs de IBM Watson.
MODELS.Q4-A-2: Las credenciales de Watson Visual Recognition creadas por el profesor tienen limitado el número de modelos de aprendizaje automático que se pueden crear con ellas. Esto se muestra en la interfaz IBM Cloud donde se llaman "custom classifiers".
MODELS.Q4-A-3: Si se excede este límite, no se podran entrenar nuevos modelos y se mostrará este mensaje:
MODELS.Q4-A-4: La clase ha superado el límite máximo de modelos que se pueden crear. Por favor, indica a tu profesor que las claves para  "Watson Visual Recognition API no tienen clasificadores disponibles".
MODELS.Q4-A-5: Si un alumno que ha entrenado con éxito un modelo lo borra, se libera un workspace que puede ser utilizado por otro alumno..
MODELS.Q4-A-6: Una forma de evitar este error puede ser limitar el tamaño de las clases. Si hay un número menor de estudiantes que el clasificadores soportados por las credenciales Watson Visual Recognition , los límites no se superarán.
MODELS.Q4-A-7: Otra forma de evitar este error  consiste en añadir más claves para Watson Assistant API o usar una intancia de Watson Visual Recognition "plan"  que tiene límites más altos.
MODELS.Q5-A-1: Los modelos de aprendizaje automático en esta herramienta usan APIs de IBM Watson.
MODELS.Q5-A-2: Si tienes una cuenta de clase "no gestionada" tu profesor habrá obteinido de IBM Cloud las credenciales de Watson API necesarias para que funcione. .
MODELS.Q5-A-3: Si se crearon cuentas gratuitas, se aplicará un límite al ratio de solicitudes de nuevos modelos de aprendizaje automátio. Normalmente, esto no tiene impacto en la clase. Sin embargo, los alumnos pueden recibir un mensajede error "no hay más workspaces disponibles " o"no hay más clasificadores disponiblles" pero pueden continuar haciendo click repetidas veces en el botón  "Entrena un nuevo modelo de aprendizaje automático" para que se aplique la limitación de velocidad.
MODELS.Q5-A-4: Los alumnos pueden recibir un mensaje como éste::
MODELS.Q5-A-5: Tu clase está haciendo demasiadas solicitudes de creación de modelos demasido rápido. Por favor, para ahora e indica al profesor que el Servicio the Watson Assistant service está aplicaneo limitación de velocidad a la clave API
MODELS.Q5-A-6: Machine Learning for Kids no aplica ni puede controlar la limitación de ratio. Normalmente es algo temporal. Lo mejor es esperar un rato..
MODELS.Q5-A-7: Si los estudianets hacen click en el botón  "Entrenar nuevo modelol" getting obtienen el erro "no hay más workspaces disponibles" o "no hay más clasificadores disponibles" entonces deben saber que hacer click repetidamente no resolverá el problema, pero puede de hecho empeorar la situación para el resto de la clase..
MODELS.Q6: Llevo siglos esperando que el modelo acabe de entrenar.
MODELS.Q6-A-2: La página debe mostrar el estatus del modelo cada 30 segundos, por a veces deja de hacer esta comprobación. Es posible que sigas esperando a que el modelo acabe de entrenar aunque el modelo ya esté listo..
MODELS.Q6-A-3: Si ha pasado mucho más que “unos pocos minutos”, conviene refrescar o volver a cargar la página..
MODELS.Q6-A-4: Si han pasado más de 10 minutos, lo recommendable es reiniciarl  (Haz click en el botón Cancelar y después en el botón entrenar nuevo modelo.).
MODELS.Q7: "Your class is sharing Watson API keys ... there are currently none available"
MODELS.Q7-A-1: Machine learning models in the tool are created using IBM Watson APIs.
MODELS.Q7-A-2: If you have a "managed" class account, this means your class is sharing these keys with many other schools.
MODELS.Q7-A-3: There are normally enough for all schools, but if it is very busy and all of the available API keys are currently in use, attempts to train new machine learning models will fail, and this message will be displayed:
MODELS.Q7-A-4: Your class is sharing Watson Assistant / Visual Recognition "API keys" with many other schools, and unfortunately there are currently none available. Please let your teacher or group leader know that you will have to train your machine learning model later
MODELS.Q7-A-5: If a student who has a successfully trained model then deletes their model, this will free up a workspace for use by another student.
MODELS.Q7-A-6: The best thing to do is to try again later, after other students have deleted their machine learning models and API keys are available again. Your training data will still be safe until then.
MODELS.Q7-A-7: Another way to avoid this error is for your class to create an "unmanaged" class account, which is where a teacher creates their own Watson "API keys" that can be dedicated only for use by their own class.

TEACHERUI.TITLE: Profesor: Problema con la interfaz de administración
TEACHERUI.Q2: Falta una cuenta de usuarios de la lista que aparece en la pagina de profesor
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-1: La gestión de usuarios se hace mediante un Servicio de terceros e, Auth0.
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-2: En ocasiones, la lista de alumnos puede quedar un poco desactualizada y no reflejar alumnos creados o borrados recientemente.).
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-3: En estos casos, los alumnos sí que se han creado o borrado correctamente. Tan solo no se reflejan los últimos cambios en la lista.
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-4: La herramienta de administración de usuarios Auth0 normalmente reportará estos casos en su página de estatus como retraso en la indexación de usuarios o problemas con la API de búsqueda.
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-5: Lo mejor en estos casos es esperar a que se actualice correctament la indexación de  Auth0.
TEACHERUI.Q4: ¿Por qué se borran los modelos de forma automática?
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-1: Cuando se creó Machine Learning for Kids , las escuelas solicitaron esta característica para facilitar la gestión de los modelos de aprendizaje automático creados por cada clase..
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-2: La herramienta borra automáticamente los modelos al acabar la clase, en lugar de pedir a los alumnos que lo hagan ellos mismos para que los compañeros de la clase siguiente puedan crear sus modelos sin problemas. Resulta mucho más cómodo y sencillo que realizer borrados manuals.  .
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-3: Se puede configurar el límite temporal tras el cual se borran los modelos. En una escuela donde las clases duren 1 o 2 horas, puede ser razonable borrar los modelos al cabo de dos horas. Para un club de programación seminal, será más apropiado establecer el límite de borrado en 6 días..
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-4: Para indicar los límites temporalis de una clase, ve a la página a la sección Restricciones dentro de la página del profesor..
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-6: Nota: Se borran automáticamente los modelos de aprendizaje automático, pero los datos de entrenamiento usados para crearlos se consevan. Por tanto, si se borra un modelo de un proyecto en el que todavía está trabajando un alumnos, siempre puede hacer click en el botón "Entrenar" y volver a crear de nuevo el modelo.

ACCOUNTISSUES.TITLE: Problemas con las cuentas
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q1: ¿Cuál es la diferencia entre crear una cuenta o usar "Prueba ahora"?
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q1-A-1: Usar "Prueba ahora" significa que no hace falata iniciar sesión ni crear una cuenta. No hay contraseñas que los alumnos deban recordar, ni necesidad de que los profesores aporten datos personales. También ahorra a los profesores el tiempo necesario para gestionar las cuentas de alumnos. s.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q1-A-2: No obstante, al crear una cuenta se habilitan opciones adicionales. Los alumnos pueden guardar su trabajo y volver sobre él en una sesión posterior. Pueden trabajar en grupo con otros compañeros de clase. Pueden acceder desde su casa y enseñar a su familia lo que han hecho en clase. e.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q1-A-3: Abajo se puede ver un breve resumen de las diferencias.:
ACCOUNTISSUES.TRAINMODELS: Entrena un modelo de aprendizaje automático para que reconozca---
ACCOUNTISSUES.WORK_ON_PROJECTS: Trabajar con proyectos de aprendizaje automático..
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2: He creado una cuenta de clase pero mi cuenta de profesor no funciona
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2-A-1: Verifica tu dirección de correo para poder de iniciar sesión.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2-A-2: Cuando creas la cuenta de la clase, se envía un correo a la dirección facilitada con un enlace. Al hacer click sobre él, tu dirección de correo se verifica y la cuenta de clase se active. Entonces, podrás iniciar session..
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2-A-3: Si todavía no has visto el correo de verificación, revista la carpeta de correo no deseado. r.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2-A-4: Si todavía no aparece, , avísame e intentaré ayudarte.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-2: Los alumnos no pueden borrar sus propias cuentas.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-3: Un profesor siempre puede borrar una cuenta de alumno desde la página "Proferos" , haciendo click sobre el botón  "Borrar cuenta de alumno".
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-4: Esto borrará toda la información almacenada sobre este alumno, sus proyectos y sus modelos.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-7: Al borrar una cuenta de profesor se borra la de toda la clase. No se puede deshacer.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-8: Puede hacerse desde el botón "Borrar clase" que aparece en la sección Opciones Avanzadas de la página del profesor
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4: ¿Qué información se guarda de los usuarios?
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-2: Se guarda el nombre de usuarios, y la dirección de correo facilitada para crear la cuenta. La necesito para poder contactar con vosotros. .
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-4: Se guarda el nombre de usuarios de las cuentas de alumno, para que puedna iniciar sesión. No se guarda ninguna dirección, datos de contacto , ni identificador personal de los alumnos,.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-5: Recomiendo que los alumnos tengan nombres genéricos (por ejempo, alumno1) , para que no se les pueda identificar fuera de la escuela o del club de programación.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-6: Información general sobre todas las cuentas.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-7: La gestión de usuarios de Machine Learning for Kids se lleva a cabo mediante un Servicio de terceros, Auth0. Almacenan la dirección IP del ultimo inicio de session y el tipo de navegador usado. Nunca he encontrado una razón para usarlo, pero se guarda por si resulta necesario..
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-8: Los errors del navegador se recogen mediante un servicio de tercerosa Sentry. Si algo falla, recogerá la información del error, incluyendo nombre de usurio, dirección IP, tipo de navegador y una descripción técnica de lo que ha fallado.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-9: Uso Google Analytics para saber cuántos usuarios visitan visit Machine Learning for Kids cada día. Aunque también recoge información geográfica o tipo de navegador, esto solo puedo verlo de forma agregada y anonimizada.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q5: ¿Qué sucede con los datos de capacitación creados por los estudiantes?
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q5-A-1: A step in all machine learning projects that students make using this site is to create or collect training examples. For text projects, this can mean typing in short text passages. For image projects, this can means drawing pictures onto an on-screen canvas or taking photos using the webcam. For numbers projects, this means typing in sets of numbers
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q5-A-2: All of these training examples are stored in a MySQL database hosted on IBM Cloud, in Dallas in the United States. As the database administrator, I have access to all of these training examples for all student projects, however I do not use it for any other purposes other than enabling students to access and work on their own projects. I do not publish the training data (either publicly or to individuals or third parties) or otherwise share it, with the two exceptions of submitting it to IBM Watson APIs described below.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q5-A-3: Machine learning models for text projects are created using the IBM Watson Assistant cloud service, which means when students train a model, a copy of the training examples that they have entered will be submitted to IBM Watson. (The location of this cloud service is something that teachers choose when creating API keys.) IBM Watson does not use these training examples for any other purposes. This is because Machine Learning for Kids requests an opt-out for student training examples being used by IBM to improve the service, as described in the Watson documentation.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q5-A-4: Machine learning models for images projects are created using the IBM Visual Recognition cloud service, which means when students train a model, a copy of their training images will be uploaded to IBM Watson. (The location of this cloud service is something that teachers choose when creating API keys.) IBM Watson does not use these training examples for any other purposes. This is because Machine Learning for Kids requests an opt-out for student training examples being used by IBM to improve the service, as described in the Watson documentation.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q5-A-5: IBM Watson provides some general guidance for sharing training data with their services, which also apply to training data created and collected in Machine Learning for Kids. Specifically, students should be advised not to include personally identifiable information in the examples that they collect.

APIKEYSGUIDE.TITLE: Guia de IBM Cloud

INTRO.INTRO_1: Teachers / parents / code club-leaders with unmanaged class accounts need to provide 'API Keys' from IBM Cloud. These are secret codes that provide access to the artificial intelligence technology that will power student projects.
INTRO.INTRO_2: Text projects need a 'Watson Assistant' API Key. Image projects need a 'Visual Recognition' API Key. (Numbers and Sound projects don't require API Keys).
INTRO.INTRO_3: You will need to create an account on IBM Cloud to be able to create these codes. It is free to create an account, and there are no charges for 'Lite' API Keys.

APIKEYSGUIDE.EXPLANATION: Download a step-by-step guide for how to create API Keys on IBM Cloud

INTRO.INTRO_1: Machine Learning for Kids provides pre-trained models you can use in your projects. Real-world machine learning projects often use models already trained by other people. There are lots of well-trained models that are freely available, and these are useful when you don't have time to collect the amount of training data needed to train your own.

HOWTO.TITLE: Cómo usar
HOWTO.INTRO: Click on the button to go to Scratch.
HOWTO.HOW_1: Go to the version of Scratch 3 available from Machine Learning for Kids.
HOWTO.HOW_2: Pre-trained models are available from the Extensions panel. Click on the blue extensions button in the bottom-left of the Scratch window to find them, then click on the one you want to add to your project.
HOWTO.HOW_3: The blocks for the pre-trained model will be added to the Scratch toolbox.

SPEECHTOTEXT.TITLE: Speech to text
SPEECHTOTEXT.SPEECH_1: This model can be used to recognize speech recorded through your microphone.
SPEECHTOTEXT.SPEECH_2: It gives you a block you can use to record some audio and then give you the text that it recognized, and a block that you can tell it to listen out for a particular word or phrase.
SPEECHTOTEXT.SPEECH_3: It uses the speech recognition capability that comes with Google Chrome, so the ML model that you'll be using comes from Google. (It also means that you can only use this model if you're using the Google Chrome web browser, sorry!)

FACEAPI.TITLE: Reconocimiento facial
FACEAPI.FACE_1: This model can be used to recognize your face in the video feed from your webcam.
FACEAPI.FACE_2: It gives you blocks that will find the x,y coordinates of your eyes, nose and mouth.
FACEAPI.FACE_3: The technique this uses is called an SSD (which stands for Single Shot Multibox Detector) and is based on MobileNet (a ML model designed for mobile devices, so it doesn't need much computing power).
FACEAPI.FACE_4: The training data used for this model came from a set known as WIDER FACE.

POSENET.TITLE: Pose detection
POSENET.POSE_1: This model can be used to recognize your pose in the video feed from your webcam.
POSENET.POSE_2: It gives you blocks that will find the x,y coordinates of different parts of your body, like shoulders, elbows, wrists, knees, and ankles.
POSENET.POSE_3: This uses a bottom-up technique - looking for human body key points (like shoulders, elbows, knees, etc.) and then grouping them to identify a person and the pose that they're in. The technique is based on MobileNet (a ML model designed for mobile devices, so it doesn't need much computing power).
POSENET.POSE_4: The training data used for this model came from a set known as Common Objects in Context (COCO).
